properties.name: The Old Finsbury Town Hall
properties.description: Opened by Lord Rosebery, an ornate building with elegant decor influenced by the Art Nouveau movement. Several notable rooms including the Great Hall with unique stained glass, antique mirrors and Clerkenwell Angel statuettes.

properties.name: Hampstead Friends Meeting House
properties.description:
Listed Arts and Crafts freestyle building with plain interior and many charming original features, sympathetically modernised in 1991. Entrance via listed gateway.
NOTE Please wear facemasks.

properties.name: Garrick's Temple to Shakespeare, Hampton
properties.description: Grade I listed Georgian garden building. Tribute to Shakespeare built in the Ionic style by actor David Garrick. Arcadian Thames-side setting in restored 18C gardens thought to be by Capability Brown.

properties.name: Hampstead Garden Suburb Artisans' Quarter Walk
properties.description: Guided walks of 'the most nearly perfect example of the 20C Garden Suburb' (Pevsner), designed by Unwin & Parker, Lutyens, Bunney, Baillie Scott and others. Informally laid out terraces and picturesque Arts and Crafts vernacular cottages.

properties.name: 8 Stoneleigh Terrace (Highgate New Town, Stage 1)
properties.description: Built during the golden era of Camden public housing under Borough Architect Sydney Cook. Peter Tábori  studied with Ernő Goldfinger and worked with Denys Lasdun, and met Ken Adie when both were students at the Regent Street Polytechnic.

properties.name: Institut français du Royaume-Uni
properties.description: 1939 Art Deco Grade II listed building refurbished in 1950, then restructured and modernised in 2014. Contains an authentically classic cinema, private salons and multimedia library.

properties.name: London Museum of Water & Steam
properties.description: The Museum is housed within in a unique collection of Grade I and II listed buildings. Even though they were purpose-built and purely functional buildings, the architect took great care to make the buildings aesthetically pleasing.

properties.name: Markfield Beam Engine and House
properties.description:
A masterpiece of Victorian engineering, Markfield Beam Engine provided a vital public health facility from 1855-1964. 

Steaming demonstrations, 4 & 5 Sept from 12.30pm.

Set in Markfield Park along side the River Lee.

properties.name: Museum of London Docklands
properties.description: Grade I listed, late Georgian sugar warehouse now housing the Museum of London Docklands. Sensitively restored, the new multimedia displays coexist with the massive timber and brick structures of the original building.

properties.name: Pitzhanger Manor & Gallery
properties.description: Designed by Sir John Soane as a family home and country residence. Following a three-year conservation project,  Pitzhanger has been returned to Soane’s innovative original design and re-opened to the public in March 2019.

properties.name: Guildhall Art Gallery
properties.description: Houses the City of London's art collection, built over remains of London's 2C Roman amphitheatre. Façade uses Portland stone and Collyweston stone slates. Interior uses finishes of marble, American elm, damask and painted wall coverings.

properties.name: St Augustine's Tower
properties.description: Grade I listed, remaining tower of medieval parish church, with working late 16C clock. New exhibition of Hackney's history. Extensive views from roof. (Organised by Hackney Historic Buildings Trust).

properties.name: The City Churches: St Stephen Walbrook
properties.description: Wren's own and 'finest City Church'.  Fantastic architecture with different shapes,  twelve Corinthian columns and covered by huge dome - first of its type. Central stone altar by Henry Moore installed in 1987. Birthplace of the Samaritans.

properties.name: Brixton Windmill
properties.description: One of very few windmills in London. Built 1816 when Brixton Hill was open fields and a working mill until 1934. Restored to working order 2011.

properties.name: The Great Barn, Harmondsworth
properties.description: The timbers of this great medieval barn (1426-7), over 190 feet long and nearly 40 feet high, are 95% original. Displays include the conservation/repairs carried out in 2014 and its place in the agricultural history of the village.

properties.name: Argentine Ambassador's Residence
properties.description: Known as the 'Independent North Mansion' and christened by Sydney Herbert as 'Belgrave Villa' and then simply 'The Villa' by his successor the 6th Duke of Richmond. Owned by Argentina since 1936 and with sumptuous interiors still intact.

properties.name: The Ismaili Centre
properties.description: Part of an international family of Ismaili Centres, a religious, cultural and social space for the Shia Ismaili Muslim community. The serenity of the entrance fountain to the roof garden reflects Muslim traditions in architecture and design

properties.name: The Royal Society
properties.description: A spectacular Grade I listed building designed by famed architect John Nash. Built in 1831, these former townhouses have undergone refurbishments throughout their history. The building is now home to the UK's national science academy.

properties.name: Trellick Tower
properties.description: Goldfinger's 31-storey social housing tower is one of London's most remarkable high-rises. Monumental, with its free-standing service tower and triumphal boiler house, Trellick retains beautiful detailing and a rich use of materials.

properties.name: Union Chapel
properties.description: Online only. An architectural Grade I treasure that’s home to an inclusive church, an award winning venue, a unique organ and The Margins Project for those homeless and in crisis in London.

properties.name: The Church of Our Most Holy Redeemer
properties.description: A unique II* listed Italianate church by John Dando Sedding with attached Campanile and Institute Building. Of particular significance in the church is the imposing baldacchino over the High Altar, which dominates the east end.

properties.name: St Dunstan and All Saints Church
properties.description: Grade I listed early medieval parish church (from 952 before Tower of London) in spacious churchyard. Fine interior: Anglo-Saxon Rood, Norman font, 'squint', fine memorials incl founders of Trinity House, 1950s glass. Bells of Stepney.

properties.name: St Jude on the Hill
properties.description: Eccentric Edwardian church, Grade I listed. Described by Simon Jenkins as 'one of Lutyens' most distinctive creations'. Extensive 20C wall-paintings by Walter Starmer, memorial to horses of WWI. Local archives display.

properties.name: St Paul's, Newington
properties.description: Modern architecture church with large copper and lead roof and concrete, brick and stained glass external structure. Marble, wood and plaster interior and artwork by Sculptor Freda Pinto and Gerald Holtom.

properties.name: The Old Palace, Bromley Civic Centre
properties.description: Old Palace was the official residence of the Bishops of Rochester. Present building dates from 1775, although there have been manor houses on the site since 10C.

properties.name: Bushy House
properties.description: Original house was built for Edward Proger. From 1797 the residence of William, Duke of Clarence (later William IV) and his mistress Dora Jordan. Now part of the National Physical Laboratory (NPL).

properties.name: Chiswick House
properties.description: One of the earliest and finest examples of Neo-Palladian design in the UK, Chiswick House is an 18C villa in west London. The 65 acres of Grade I listed gardens are the birthplace of the English Landscape Movement.

properties.name: Cranford Stable Block & St Dunstan's Church
properties.description: 18th century stables of former Cranford House, seat of the Earls of Berkeley. Ha-ha and enclosed courtyard (the Secret Garden). St. Dunstan's Church with 17th century funeral monuments; 20th century work by Martin Travers.

properties.name: The Caledonian Club
properties.description: Built in Neoclassical style for Hugh Morrison (1868-1931), this was the last mansion house of its kind to be built in London. The club, founded in 1891, moved to the premises in 1946.

properties.name: St Peter-in-the-Forest Church & Community Centre
properties.description: An 'Italian Romanesque' church set in Epping Forest, St Peter's was founded in 1840 and extended in 1887. The building underwent a major reordering throughout 2020 to save it from subsidence and create new community facilities.

properties.name: St Lawrence Church, Morden
properties.description: Grade I listed Norman brick-built church consisting of a nave and chancel. Tower at the west end. Gothic-style stone windows from the old church inserted into the present 1636 structure. East window stone likely to be from Merton Priory.

properties.name: The Chapter House, Merton Priory
properties.description: Fascinating excavated foundations of the Chapter House of Merton Priory c1100-1200, one of the most important of all Augustinian monasteries prior to its destruction in 1538 by Henry VIII. The remains lie under Merantun Way (A24).

properties.name: Whitehall Historic House
properties.description: Originally a farmer's house dating to 1500, with jettied upper storey. Later additions reflect the changing lifestyles of the owners, including the Killicks for over two centuries. Now houses scale model of Henry VIII's Nonsuch Palace.

properties.name: Little Holland House (online only)
properties.description: Closed for refurbishment. Grade II listed building inspired by the ideals of John Ruskin and William Morris and contains Dickinson's paintings, hand-made furniture, furnishings, metalwork and friezes, in Arts & Crafts style.

properties.name: Carshalton Water Tower and Historic Gardens
properties.description: Early 18C Grade II listed building incorporating plunge bath with Delft tiles, orangery, saloon and pump chamber with part-restored water wheel. Hermitage and sham bridge in grounds.

properties.name: St George's German Lutheran Church
properties.description: The oldest surviving German church in England from 1763 with unaltered Georgian interior including box pews, German memorials and wheezy German Walcker organ from 1870.

properties.name: Gap House
properties.description: Family home with a minimal carbon footprint on a very narrow site (8ft wide). Environmentally friendly house, utilising amongst many eco-friendly devices ground source heat pump heating & rainwater harvesting. RIBA Manser Medal Winner 2009.

properties.name: A Ruskinian Walk Through Shared Heritage
properties.description: Ruskinian walk from RIBA award-winning Chiswick Business Park, Gunnersbury Triangle Nature Reserve through South Acton Estate, birthplace of artist Patrick Caulfield; Woodlands Park Ice House; to home of Wm Willett, of Daylight Saving Time

properties.name: Mark Masons' Hall
properties.description: This Victorian building is situated next door to St James' Palace. Fronted in stone in a 'Grosvenor Hotel' Italianate style, coarse foliage ornamentation adorns the facade with grand interiors adapted for Masonic use in the 1970s.

properties.name: Romanian Cultural Institute
properties.description: Situated in one of the largest and grandest 19th century squares in London, 1 Belgrave Square was acquired by Romania in 1936 and is now home to the Romanian Cultural Institute.

properties.name: St Nicholas Church, Chislehurst
properties.description: Medieval Parish Church, 15C, enlarged & rebuilt in 19C. Shingle spire 1857, by Wollaston. Chancel by Ferrey, lengthened with East wall by Bodley & Garner. Scadbury Chapel (Walsingham tombs), with rood screen. Clock by Dent, 1858.

properties.name: Roca London Gallery
properties.description: A unique space where water acts as the architectural theme - offering an innovative and interactive experience with Roca, the global bathroom brand.

properties.name: Sandys Row Synagogue
properties.description: Built as a Huguenot chapel in 1763, this building has been in continuous use as a synagogue since 1860 retains many original features including the gallery. Oldest  remaining Ashkenazi synagogue in London and third oldest in the country.

properties.name: Darbishire Place (Peabody Whitechapel Estate)
properties.description: New block of 13 homes which completes an ensemble of six housing blocks surrounding an internal courtyard.The façade complements the existing Victorian buildings by Henry Astley Darbishire. RIBA Award Winner & Stirling Prize shortlist 2015

properties.name: 8a Belsize Court Garages (online only)
properties.description: Originally a late 19C coachman's living quarters and stable, this mews house combines an award-winning architect's studio and spacious light-filled maisonette after a 2-phase carbon-reducing retrofit.

properties.name: The Wheelhouse
properties.description: Listed building with unique 7-spoke Victorian waterwheel, the only daily working example in South London, originally used by Liberty's for rinsing printed silk, and now the home of a craft pottery and art studio.

properties.name: Cressingham Gardens
properties.description: Low-rise high density estate located next to Brockwell Park. Innovative design with pioneering architectural elements & echoing natural topography. Under threat of demolition by Lambeth council. Tours provided of estate and rotunda.

properties.name: Roehampton University- Digby Stuart campus
properties.description: This tour of the university campus is a walk through the history of architecture. Starting in 1790  with Grove House and finishing with the University library completed in 2018, and short listed for the Stirling Prize.

properties.name: German Historical Institute
properties.description: This Grade II* listed building includes an Adam-style ceiling on the 1st floor and a beautiful staircase with wrought-iron balustrade. Once home to the Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain, it now houses an historical research institute.

properties.name: St Mary of Eton Church Mixed Use Development
properties.description: Spacious Refurbished Grade II* listed church with new community facilities, new housing. 2015 RIBA Award, New London Architecture Award, Housing Design Award.

properties.name: The Library at Willesden Green
properties.description: A modern 4-storey building incorporating the much-loved Victorian library. The galleries and feature walls display exhibitions and contemporary art and a dramatic central atrium provides natural ventilation and daylight throughout.

properties.name: Anise Gallery / AVR London
properties.description: An 1870s Zion Chapel on the Malham Road industrial Estate recently renovated into a family home. Guided tours of the Old Chapel will be available throughout the day.

properties.name: Blackheath Society Historic Walk, Blackheath SE3
properties.description: Neil Rhind will lead this historic walk along the north and east side of the Heath.

properties.name: NOW Gallery and The Gateway Pavilions
properties.description: The NOW Gallery is an art space - contained within two curved glass pavilions linked by a patinated brass-edged canopy - which defines the southern edge of Peninsula Square and acts as a gateway to the south, the cable car and Central Park.

properties.name: Central Hill Estate
properties.description: Tree-lined housing estate on the ridge of Central Hill & Crystal Palace, incorporating open spaces, views over London, gardens and sense of community. Rosemary Stjernstedt Ted Hollamby Adrian Sansom, Lambeth Borough Architects 1963.

properties.name: The School of Historical Dress
properties.description: Now home to the School of Historical Dress, the building was originally built in 1841 as the 'Royal South London Dispensary' for the working poor which closed in 1917. Bethlem used it as the Hospital for Nervous Diseases from 1920 to 1927.

properties.name: Koestler Arts Centre – Former Governor's House of HM Prison Wormwood Scrubs
properties.description: The home of the UK's leading prison arts charity, Koestler Arts. Based in the former governor's house of HMP Wormwood Scrubs, paintings, drawings & sculptures from the Koestler Awards, all for sale, cover the walls of the 3-storey building.

properties.name: Turning Earth Ceramics E10
properties.description: Ceramics centre for the Lee Valley, covering the entire top floor of an old hardware factory. Three rooms, providing just over 8000 sq ft of floor space; the main room is capped by its original saw-tooth glass roof feature.

properties.name: Eleanor Palmer Primary School Science Lab
properties.description: A timber STEM building conceived as a ‘wonder room’, a place for discovery and experimentation, used as a shared resource with local primary schools and the community. RIBA National Award Winner and Wood Award High Commendation in 2019.

properties.name: Shrewsbury House
properties.description: Built in 1923, to replace its 18C namesake, Grade ll listed Shrewsbury House is the focus of the Shrewsbury Park Estate conservation area, built 1934-1936 by John Laing and Sons. Two Civil Defence centres are within the grounds.

properties.name: Polish Social and Cultural Association
properties.description: Built 1971-74 in brutalist style. The largest Polish centre in Western Europe, it contains a theatre, the Polish Library, the Polish University Abroad, a Joseph Conrad collection, Jazz Café, art gallery and art collection on public display.

properties.name: Hanwell Community Centre
properties.description: Victorian Grade II listed former Central London District School, known as the 'Cuckoo Schools', was 'home' to up to 1500 pauper children from inner London from 1857-1933.

properties.name: Estorick Collection of Modern Italian Art
properties.description: The Estorick Collection is housed in a beautiful Georgian building previously known as Northampton Lodge. Today, the museum comprises six galleries over three floors, as well as a library, offices, a café and bookshop.

properties.name: Elephant Park
properties.description: Elephant Park is a unique, new two-acre park in Elephant & Castle that boasts Elephant Springs - a spectacular new natural stone and water landscape. Meet the design team and get a guided tour of this new green oasis in the heart of London.

properties.name: Westbourne Park Baptist Church
properties.description: The building is a church worship area with an additional hall, meeting rooms, offices, a children's library and 33 affordable units of accommodation made up of one, two and three bedroom flats.

properties.name: St Margaret's Church, Lee
properties.description:
The Church was built in 1839/41 as a white 'Hall-Church'. 
The 1870s Gothic Revivalism was overseen to a very high standard, by James Brooks and helped by 10 top craftsmen of the day. We also have a WWI Memorial by Violet Pinwill.

properties.name: Cut Glass Studio Ltd, Tottenham Hale
properties.description: Unit used as an art studio in a small industrial estate.

properties.name: Ss Peter & Paul Church
properties.description:
Nave (1844) by Lewis Vulliamy, chancel (1903) by Sir Arthur Blomfield. Stained glass windows by Christopher Webb and 
by Clayton & Bell. Norman font brought from the Old Church. Grade II* listed.

properties.name: PEER
properties.description: PEER is a gallery with a 10-metre wide glass façade, bringing art straight onto the street. With its community garden, and Chris Ofili's 'Black Hands' outdoor clock, PEER is also a welcoming and open public space.

properties.name: Trevithick House
properties.description: Pre war social housing flats, red brick, Georgian sash windows, playground, allotments and washing lines outside.

properties.name: Ram Quarter
properties.description:
Tour the UK’s oldest brewery site, once home to Young’s.
Architect’s walk/talk covers history & redevelopment, incl. new boulevard, square, river walk & restored listed buildings.
Possible access to residential and brewery heritage areas.

properties.name: Museum of Neoliberalism
properties.description: The museum is situated in a shopfront in Leegate Shopping Centre, which has been described by the Evening Standard as "the worst shopping precinct in the country."

properties.name: Fitzroy Park Allotments
properties.description: open allotment site, no buildings

properties.name: Holy Cross Church, Cromer Street
properties.description: Grade ll listed Oxford Movement Anglican church built 1887-88. Historic England describe the exterior as ‘quirky and aggressive’ but the  interior is ‘very spare and elegant, the proportions subtly adjusted’. Elevated choir and sanctuary.

properties.name: StreetGym® Urban Adventure
properties.description: StreetGym® is a one hour, circular urban adventure where we jog from workstation to workstation.  A workstation is an item of street furniture, gradient or architectural feature where we perform bodyweight exercises.

properties.name: Hackney Marshes Walk
properties.description: Hackney Marshes is of London wide importance. Common land on the front line against urban pressure on green space and rivers. Led by Hackney Marshes Users Group who have for many years organised locally to defend and improve the Marshes

properties.name: Slavery and the City
properties.description: We will explore sites and institutions with direct links to the history of slavery and hear why the apologies were made last year, whilst wandering within the story packed streets and alleyways of the Square Mile.

properties.name: Wharf Road
properties.description: Designed by architects Pollard Thomas Edwards, the £50m scheme delivered 98 new homes. 80 per cent of the homes are affordable including 64 for social rent. Wharf Road is set around two new communal gardens that face Regents canal.

properties.name: Celebrating workplaces of key workers: Amazing Parks - a virtual tour with a London Blue Badge Tourist Guide
properties.description: Parks were a lifeline for many during lockdown - yet many of us take them for granted. This virtual walk looks at the history of parks in Southwark paying tribute to the pioneers who fought to provide open space to the public.

properties.name: Lanterna, Fish Island Village
properties.description: Designed by Lyndon Goode Architects, Lanterna acts as a gateway to our Fish Island Village development with Hill and was shortlisted for a prestigious Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA) London Award for architectural excellence.

properties.name: Rushmore (online only)
properties.description: Rear extension and complete transformation of the Lower Ground Floor of a Victorian House, featuring modern and minimal materials like concrete & plywood.

properties.name: 9 Lanbury Road
properties.description: Extension and refurbishment of a 2-storey "home for heroes" terraced house with open-plan modern layout and minimal aesthetic. The extension features exposed bricks and timber joists with bespoke bamboo kitchen and paneling.

properties.name: Hedge Lane
properties.description: Remodelling and extension of rear of house to make a kitchen/diner/lounge with ancillary wc and utility spaces.

properties.name: Hyde Park Chapel
properties.description: The four-story Church façade and prominent seven-story tower is covered in Portland stone and highlighted by a golden steeple. The interior features the Christus statue and a large mural of the resurrected Jesus Christ.

properties.name: St Bride's Church, Fleet Street
properties.description: Wren designed building of 1675, interior lost in blitz of 1940, reopened 1957 with 'Wren inspired' interior

properties.name: Boston Manor House and Park Walks
properties.description:
Visitors will be shown around Boston Manor Park on short walks led by volunteers, focusing on the History of Boston Manor House and area.
The House is closed as part of a 5 year redevelopment project, re-opening early 2022.

properties.name: Battersea's Hidden Parks
properties.description: Walking tour introducing nine smaller local parks and public gardens, and revealing their history. Led by Clare Graham, Chair of the Society's Open Spaces Committee and author of 'Discovering Battersea's Open Spaces: a walking guide'.

properties.name: University of Chicago Booth School of Business
properties.description: Chicago Booth's London campus combines the best of old and new. Located near St. Paul's, the campus features more than 50 pieces of contemporary art and houses our Executive MBA Programme Europe, Executive Education, and conference centre.

properties.name: Ripple Greenway and the Lost Words Art Trail
properties.description:
Ripple Greenway is a beautiful 14-acre linear park and art trail.  Home to Katy Hallett’s steel sculptures, inspired by Robert Macfarlane’s and Jackie Morris’ The Lost Words.
Wooden play and exercise equipment, picnic tables and benches.

properties.name: The Old Deanery
properties.description: This Grade I Mansion House, close to St Paul's Cathedral was probably designed by Edward Woodroofe in 1669 and completed in 1673.  The residence of successive Deans of St Pauls until the 1970's today it is the office to the Bishop of London

properties.name: Walking tour of Unity Place, South Kilburn Estate
properties.description: A tour of Unity Place, the latest phase of Brent Council’s twenty-year South Kilburn Regeneration, led by Feilden Clegg Bradley Studios, Alison Brooks Architects,  Gort Scott, Grant Associates, and Emma Sweeney, Brent Council.

properties.name: Enfield To Fork - Pymmes Park
properties.description: The Museum of Enfield is this year bringing its temporary exhibition to you! “From Enfield to Fork” explores the borough’s history and relationship with food, from Roman Enfield to Market Gardening.

properties.name: The Great Fire of London
properties.description: The Great Fire of London

properties.name: Architecture and Art in the City
properties.description: Architecture and Art in the City

properties.name: Crime, Punishment & Executions
properties.description: Crime, Punishment & Executions in the City of London

properties.name: Ancient Livery Companies in the City of London
properties.description: Ancient Livery Companies of the City of London

properties.name: Nunnery Gallery
properties.description: In 1868 the Dominican sisters established a convent in the heart of the East End. Today, the Nunnery Gallery maintains some of its original neo-gothic features, and original hardwood floor and hosts a programme of site-responsive art.

properties.name: 186A Uxbridge Road
properties.description:
Semi-detached residential 2-bed house at the end of a total refurbishment by the owner/architect.
The main works included demolition of str. walls to achieve open plan living, new bathroom, porch, skylight, green roof, UFH and insulation.

properties.name: Lexi Cinema
properties.description: A contemporary extension to the Lexi Cinema. The building is a composition of brick and stainless steel; a nod to the parapets of surrounding terraces that reflect the changing clouds above, blending with the sky.

properties.name: 38 Grosvenor Square
properties.description: A beautiful Mayfair town house c 1727 original to the Square. Transformed 1776 by John Johnson for Duke of Dorset; magnificent staircase, lavish ‘Adamesque’ entertaining suite. Mid-C19 Italianate front by Thomas Cundy.

properties.name: House for a Cellist
properties.description: Ground floor rear extension, roof terrace and general refurbishment of a Victorian terraced house within a Conservation Area. A reflection on space continuity, compression and expansion. How a square a triangle and a circle interact.

properties.name: Self-guided Old Malden Walk
properties.description: The walk is around Old Malden and covers residential developments within the district. Different styles of suburban architecture includes a selection of modernist housing. There are also historic buildings and other places of interest.

properties.name: The Steamship Project Space
properties.description: With a sculpture garden, performance art in the attic and live music in the bowels of The Steamship, built in the heart of Docklands 1885, the resident artists show how the area has transformed and how they've transformed the former pub.

properties.name: Ashraya
properties.description: 'Ashraya' is a contemporary low carbon 'Paragraph 79' house located in the heart of the Chiltern Hills, Hertfordshire. The house was designed by British architects Kirkland Fraser Moor (KFM) and completed in 2021.

properties.name: Gareth Gardner Gallery
properties.description: Gareth Gardner Gallery is a small gallery space in Deptford, showing photography of architecture and the built environment. The fit-out was designed by architect Studio C102 and its industrial style was inspired by art gallery warehouses.

properties.name: DLR Underline Discovery Sessions
properties.description: DLR Underline Discovery Sessions covers a series of events for all ages focused on exploring the spaces under the DLR on the Isle of Dogs, with activities exploring the area's architecture, heritage and the public realm.

properties.name: AFYT present: Civic Rituals - A Love Letter to Brixton
properties.description: A walking tour led by the Architecture Foundation's Young Trustees exploring Brixton's changing identity at a critical juncture in time – the walk will be followed by an open call for responses celebrating its cultural and social fabric.

properties.name: Wellbeing Walk: South Kensington
properties.description: Our walking tour takes inspiration from the streets of South Kensington to explore practical ways to support wellbeing and find pools of calm in the midst of London's buzz and bustle.

properties.name: C1
properties.description: An open and welcoming building, intent on fostering community. A rooftop basketball court crowns three storeys of studio space, all accessible via open-air staircases doubling as communal spaces.

properties.name: Canal Club
properties.description: The Canal Club is the community Centre for Wellington Estate, designed in the 80's by the modernist architect Julian Sofaer. Its community gardens were opened later by the boating community moored alongside the centre.

properties.name: C3 - Bureau
properties.description: C3 is home to Bureau, a members club at the heart of Design District. Its undulating white facade creates informal pockets of space on the interior, ideal for flexible working models.

A three-storey decorative folly, drawing sightlines through the central park towards the Victorian terraces beyond. The structure is timber studwork, with the design featuring a galvanized steel, powder coated staircase in vibrant yellow.

properties.name: Human scale housing: East London cycle tour
properties.description: Over the last 20 years, architects have been developing unusual and innovative small-scale residential schemes which seek to improve the quality of public housing in London and reconnect residents to the streets and surrounding communities

properties.name: Eco Show Home
properties.description: Waltham Forest Council has transformed a Victorian terrace into an Eco Home to showcase best practice retrofitting to be more carbon friendly. Features home improvements that reduce carbon footprint and help tackle the climate emergency.

properties.name: The Mysterious Black Tudors - Family Trail
properties.description: Celebrate Open House Festival 2021 with this fun and interactive family event about Britain's forgotten history of the Black Tudors.
